text: when it comes to what they think of
Britain's EU referendum many world
leaders have already put their cards on
the table the American president has
come down against a brexit so has the
German Chancellor the Japanese Prime
Minister and other key plays but there
is one world leader who on brexit is
keeping his cards very close to his
chest and that is the Kremlin leader in
public poker-faced Vladimir Putin hasn't
said anything at all about Britain's
referendum mind you in Britain they've
been saying plenty about Russia the only
country if the truth is told that would
like us to leave the EU is Russia and
that should probably tell us all that we
need to know so is that true is the
Kremlin secretly betting on a brexit and
if so why what kind of a game is Russia
played ask Russian officials that
question and they'll assure you Russia
isn't even at the table I can say that
Russia has nothing to do with brexit at
all we're not involved in this process
we have no interests in this field no
interests Kremlin critics say Moscow is
bluffing
so if there's a proxy if there is a no
crisis in the European Union of course
this will be a local propaganda victory
because Moscow sees everything as a
zero-sum game so what's bad for the
European Union is good for Russia it's
just as simple as that
but why would a weaker EU deal Russia a
stronger hand
well Moscow's game plan involves getting
Brussels to scrap sanctions the
calculation may be that an EU in trouble
would do that more quickly as part of
its strategy Russia has been playing
divide and rule quoting those EU states
like Greece which are friendlier
so the stakes couldn't be higher
ahead of this evening referendum or just
for the British public but the global
players - waiting to see how the cards
fall Steve Rosenberg BBC news Moscow
